Rekka starter.
PCiel uses the Seventh Holy Scripture as a gun and fires two shots. Very safe on block and opens up for decent corner carry off of certain stray hits, but not as useful in combos when compared to the charged version.

Rekka extender.
Usable even if the first hit of the rekka whiffs.
PCiel spins while firing the Seventh Holy Scripture. Covers a fair bit of distance, making it useful as the second hit of a confirmed rekka in order to get in closer.

236[A].name: The charged version of 236A; it loses its rekka properties but in exchange acts as a great corner carry tool and overall combo flex.

236B.name: Blade II (available as a followup to 236A)

Rekka starter.
PCiel uses the Seventh Holy Scripture as a whip and slashes downwards. Covers a large amount of space and catches airborne opponents at mid to far range, but is air blockable.

Rekka extender.
Usable even if the first hit of the rekka whiffs.
PCiel whips the blades of the Seventh Holy Scripture again, this time hitting around the floor.

236[B].name: The charged version of 236[B]. The first two hits are overheads, making this a powerful low shield crush when used properly due to retaining the range of the normal Blade series.

236C.name: A move that can be used either on its own or as an immediate followup to 236A or 236B, boasting an armored forward charge for blasting through most attacks and potentially acting as a powerful counter-zoning tool. It can also be charged up to change its properties and fake out an opponent expecting it to come.
236C.advantage: +9 (always; goes into a fixed followup on block)

Armored.
Rekka ender and standalone special.
Comboable wallbounce with Special Bonus.
Bumps opponents into the air on block.
PCiel hops backwards, then rushes forwards with the Seventh Holy Scripture. The rush part of the move has armor and leads to a decently damaging combo on hit with Special Bonus. Its main downside is that it is quite slow.

623A.name: PCiel's DP. While the B and C versions are the only ones that are actually invincible, the A version has a jump cancel point if it whiffs, allowing for some tricky feints if used cautiously.
623A.advantage: -17/-9 if jump cancelled vs crouch/stand, respectively

623B.name: PCiel's DP. While the B and C versions are the only ones that are actually invincible, the A version has a jump cancel point if it whiffs, allowing for some tricky feints if used cautiously.

623C.name: PCiel's DP. While the B and C versions are the only ones that are actually invincible, the A version has a jump cancel point if it whiffs, allowing for some tricky feints if used cautiously.

214A.name: PCiel's other counter-zoning special and a situationally useful okizeme tool. It has something of a slow startup, but can cover a great deal of vertical space and no small amount of horizontal space if used correctly, allowing PCiel to stuff a lot of mid-range attacks.

214[A].name: PCiel's other counter-zoning special and a situationally useful okizeme tool. It has something of a slow startup, but can cover a great deal of vertical space and no small amount of horizontal space if used correctly, allowing PCiel to stuff a lot of mid-range attacks.

214B.name: PCiel's other counter-zoning special and a situationally useful okizeme tool. It has something of a slow startup, but can cover a great deal of vertical space and no small amount of horizontal space if used correctly, allowing PCiel to stuff a lot of mid-range attacks.

214C.name: PCiel's other counter-zoning special and a situationally useful okizeme tool. It has something of a slow startup, but can cover a great deal of vertical space and no small amount of horizontal space if used correctly, allowing PCiel to stuff a lot of mid-range attacks.

j236A.name: Air versions of +. They all lack invincibility, but the tradeoff is that they're all jump cancelable on whiff, and act as bridges out of air throw into PCiel's highest damaging air combos.
j236A.advantage: -17/-9 on tk if jump cancelled vs crouch/stand, respectively

j236B.name: Air versions of +. They all lack invincibility, but the tradeoff is that they're all jump cancelable on whiff, and act as bridges out of air throw into PCiel's highest damaging air combos.
j236B.advantage: -17/-9 on tk if jump cancelled vs crouch/stand, respectively

j236C.name: Air versions of +. They all lack invincibility, but the tradeoff is that they're all jump cancelable on whiff, and act as bridges out of air throw into PCiel's highest damaging air combos.
j236C.advantage: -21/-9 on tk if jump cancelled vs crouch/stand, respectively

j214A.name: Air versions of +. They functionally serve similar purposes as their grounded version, but with some more recovery time due to falling from the execution area. The air stall they cause does, however, make certain types of counterattack from the opponent more likely to whiff in exchange.

j214[A].name: Air versions of +. They functionally serve similar purposes as their grounded version, but with some more recovery time due to falling from the execution area. The air stall they cause does, however, make certain types of counterattack from the opponent more likely to whiff in exchange.

j214C.name: Air versions of +. They functionally serve similar purposes as their grounded version, but with some more recovery time due to falling from the execution area.
